acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 98.1 mg BeF2/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 18.8 mg beryllium/kg (DFGOT Vol.21 (2005)).

aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
aspiration_hazard.rationale:
"Inhalation of dust or fume may cause chemical pneumonia" (ICSC (J) (2000)).
According to the technical guideline, "metal dust of beryllium fluoride may produce chemical pneumonia following inhalation exposure etc. In the ICSC card, under the heading of 'important data,' it says 'inhalation of dust/fume may cause chemical pneumonia,' and the following chemicals are listed as examples" (ICSC (J) (2000)). The present substance is assumed to be included in the list and thus classified into Category 2 for "Aspiration hazard."

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category K (Beryllium (CAS 7440-41-7) and Beryllium Compounds) by NTP (2005) and Category 1 (BERYLLIUM AND BERYLLIUM COMPOUNDS) by IARC (1993).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale:
No data available
As for the reproductive mutagenicity of beryllium compounds and inorganic fluorides, refer to "ID487, Beryllium Sulfate, CAS: 7787-56-6" and  "ID479, Sodium Fluoride, CAS: 7681-49-4" respectively.

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being inorganic compounds containing fluorine.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the human epidemiological evidence of "redness, pain and blurred vision" (ICSC (2000)), "irritation" (HSDB (2006)), and the description in ICSC (2000): Short term exposure produces "severe irritation of the eye." The substance is thus considered a severe eye irritant.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the human epidemiological evidence of "skin edema following exposure to dust" (ATSDR (2002), "redness and pain" (ICSC (2000)) and "irritation" (HSDB (2006)), and the description in ICSC (2000): Short-term exposure produces "severe irritation of the skin." The substance is thus considered a severe skin irritant.

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Based on the evidence of "delayed dermal reactions" from guinea pig skin sensitization tests (ATSDR (2002)). Also based on the description in the report on sensitization tests in guinea pigs (DFGOT Vol.21 (2005)): "26 of 33 Harley guinea pigs, five of 10 Pirbright guinea pigs and eight of 11 inbred guinea pigs demonstrated positive responses." Also based on the human epidemiological evidence: "All 13 patients who had beryllium fluoride-induced dermatitis showed positive responses in patch tests."

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Stable to water (highly soluble in water, ICSC (2004))

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (respiratory system, kidney, adrenal gland, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (respiratory system, kidney, adrenal gland, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "The acute respiratory effects could be caused by inhalation of beryllium fluoride etc." (EHC 106 (1990)). Also based on the evidence from animal studies: "Histology revealed pleuritis, congestion, emphysema, consolidation, and edema of the lung; glomerular degeneration in the kidneys; marked hypoplasia and hypotrophy of the adrenal gland; hepatocyte degeneration" (ATSDR (2002)), "caused pulmonary lesions" (EHC 106 (1990)).The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale:
Based on the human evidence: "Beryllium fluoride severely irritates the eye, skin and respiratory tract; may induce chemical pneumonia following inhalation of dust or fume" (ICSC (J) (2000)).
Refer to the GHS classification of fluoride compounds, in particular "Hydrogen Fluoride" since "the severity of the effects was more notable with beryllium fluoride than with beryllium sulfate or beryllium hydrogen phosphate, partly due to the fluoride component which may form hydrofluoric acid in the lung as beryllium fluoride dissociates" (ATSDR (2002)).
